posts.name: Yoke
posts.cooked:
Obligatory warning this topic contains many personal issues I have encountered after one month using Signal. I may sound a broken record to some of you, but these are my personal experiences.

  1. No group management. I understand Signal server does not store the info necessary but this turns many contacts off. We are running WhatsApp and Telegram groups with this must have feature. edit: This includes, but not limited to: group moderation / kicking / blocking / muting members, adding moderators/admins, group description.

  2. No search functions like WhatsApp or Telegram. This is a basic function yet Signal is missing it. Edit: global search doesn’t count. WhatsApp can search in a specific chat and search group members.

  3. App performance. Telegram and WhatsApp are much slicker and smooth… Edit: try Telegram X.

  4. Pinning messages in personal or group chats.

  5. Channel feature. In WhatsApp, you can make a group as read-only to mimic Channel. Telegram has this by nature.

  6. Basic editing features. Bold, Italic, Swipe to Reply?

  7. Dark mode on iOS? Theming on all platforms? Wallpaper change?

With impending WhatsApp’s ads, I must be quick to decide where we are heading. I really can not give a recommendation to my contacts to use Signal if the other alternative (Telegram) is much more superior feature wise. Security and privacy alone will not cut it.

link_counts.title: Any power behind this negative PR?
Signal becoming like other social media apps
Mark Zuckerberg: "A Privacy-Focused Vision for Social Networking"
Talk to Signal Research (post of Signal's UX researcher on Reddit)
Using linux signal4desktop on Chrome Crostini, but it won't mirror SMS conversations?

posts.cooked:
Ellaine, thanks much for your report. I am involved in similar drama with my contacts, which I will not go into here ;-)

I do have some questions about what you are specifically wanting to see happen, however my first comment is that you SHOULD be able to search, and if you cannot it is a bug:

#2. there is actually a full-text-search feature in recent versions of signal4android, and I believe also signal4ios. This feature has not yet appeared in signal4desktop, but I believe is coming along there as well. On the main conversation-list, tap the little magnifying-glass in the top-righthand corner, and you should be able to search conversation-history, contacts, groupchats, etc. Is that not working for you? Do you have permissions to access Contacts enabled on your smartphone for signalapp?

questions about #3

#3. Are you worried about

  • speed of sending messages i.e. how many seconds it takes to deliver “hello” from france to california?
  • or, audio quality during encrypted-voice-calls and video-calls?
  • or, just the general UI/UX feel of how fast the app opens, how quickly it scrolls up in conversation-history, that sort of thing?
  • maybe all of the above :-) but which are the dealbreakers which prevent moving over? Everybody wants their apps to be as slick and fast as possible … “no perceptible slowness whatsoever” is the long-term goal … but in the short term, only SOME kinds of performance problems will be so annoying they cause people to uninstall signalapp and go back to partly-encrypted telegram or metadata-leaking whatsapp.

Which platforms do you need performance improvements on, specifically? e.g. signal4desktop is slower to open the app than signal4android, but both send messages in around 2 seconds or so measured in realtime device to device. (Typing the message itself is usually faster in signal4desktop thanks to the hardware keyboard however so the longer load-time is often worth it when having an extended conversation.)

Also worth noting, there are multiple official clients for telegram, which have very different performance-characteristics: classic telegram-app for ios and android platforms, which is GPLv2/v3-licensed, and the newer slicker tastier telegram-X thing for ios and android, which has a proprietary license.

I have no inside info, but usually in my experience when a developer tries to get people to switch from a libre-license client to a slicker/faster/featureful new client with a proprietary license, the reason is that they are planning to monetize their userbase and want to prevent any forks from appearing once that other shoe drops. Signalapp is gplv3 with no proprietary official clients, and although there are also a lot of unofficial signalapp clients running around, to my knowledge all of them are also GPLv3.

So for performance-comparisons, you need to distinguish between proprietary telegramX which is (if my hunch is correct) likely to someday have built-in-adverts or charge money per copy or otherwise be monetized in a way you will not like, versus the performance of not-as-slick telegramClassic. They are apples and oranges.

questions about #4

#4. For the pinning-feature, do you mean,

  • #4A-welcome-to-group feature where a boilerplate message that appears at the top of the groupchat-history on a per-device basis, such that every time a new groupchat member is added, they get the ‘welcome to the groupchat’ boilerplate which explains the group rules and such?

  • Or are you talking about something else, e.g. in forum-software on websites, sometimes a forum-admin can pin a forum-post so that it always appears whenever the forum-thread is opened.

  • That is more like #4B-hovering-perma-message feature, which in signalapp would be something like the ability to send a message which appeared at the bottom of the conversation-history of the device on which it was pinned ALL THE TIME, effectively getting pinned onto the top of the send-message-textarea and no longer listed in chronological ordering. You might want that kind of 4B-type feature if you have multiple groupchats for a business, some of which include customers (hovering-perma-message: “always smile at the customer”), and some of which are internal groupchats only for employees (hovering-perma-message: “keep it clean people this is for work-purposes only”).

  • You could also be talking about #4C which is pinning conversations/groupchats so their entries always stay at the top of the conversation-list, rather than getting re-sorted as new messages arrive?

questions about #5

#5. I’m not sure I understand what a “channel feature” is specifically… is it a groupchat where only the group-creator can send messages, and all the replies go to the group-creator as two-way direct messages, usually called a broadcast-feature or a message-blast feature? WhatsApp just added that a few months ago in June apparently. Or it is more like feature#1E (see below), where a subset of people can send but other are prevented from sending by the group-admins, getting an error-message when they try?

questions about #1

#1. can you be more specific about what is needed in terms of group management? ability for a group-admin to…

  • 1A. forcibly kick out another groupmember?
  • 1B. prevent others from inviting new group-members?
  • 1C. prevent others from changing the group-nickname / group-avatar-pic?
  • 1D. prevent others from changing the disappearing-message-timer?
  • 1E. prevent others from sending, but still allow them to read?
  • 1F. prevent others from reading, but still allow them to send?
  • 1G. edit/alter the posts others made, after they have already been sent out?
  • 1H. edit/alter the posts others are about to make, prior to them being sent out?
  • 1X,1Y,1Z. other, please specify?

Some of these features (A/B/C) exist in whatsapp, some of them are feature-requests for signalapp, I don’t know enough about telegram groupchats which are unencrypted-server-side so I’ve never investigated them :-)

Please state whether each feature is a dealbreaker that would prevent signalapp from being used, highly desirable but not a dealbreaker, nice to have, or not really needed. For example, many people think that 1A-kick-out is a dealbreaker, and 1B-vetted-invite is highly desirable … because if push comes to shove, 1A is a more important feature than 1B, since if somebody in the group refuses to stop inviting others the group-admin can kick THAT person out of the group for disruption (1B is desired because it prevents a non-admin from re-inviting the disruptive person back in… plus is more narrow of a control that is less of a tactical-nuke type of option that kicking a person out feels like).

On signalapp at present, group-management is primarily social: be careful who you invite into the group, explain the rules of group-etiquette carefully (e.g. only certain folks are ‘allowed’ to invite new group-members and only certain folks are ‘allowed’ to post alerts… these are not software-enforced but merely socially-enforced). In the worst case, there is the strategic-nuke-option with signalapp: simply announce that groupchat#1 is being abandoned, and create a new groupchat#2 wherein you ONLY invite people that were not causing disruption in groupchat#1.

This sort of destroy-the-groupchat-to-save-the-groupchat move is not as pleasant as the tactical-nuke feature request (ability to specify groupchat admins who can forcibly kick out bad apples from the groupchat), but it does suffice as a workaround for MANY – but not all – kinds of groupchats in signalapp. Typically the vast majority of groupchats contain only participants who know and trust each other, and thus nobody would add a bad apple into the encrypted groupchat, since that defeats the purpose of encrypting communications in the first place. If you are planning on making groupchats which contain untrusted participants, unknown participants, or outright adversarial participants, then group-management features suddenly become far more important. Can you give us some idea of what kind of groupchats you and your contacts are envisioning, which is to say, why you need specific group-management features?

Do you have a link for this advert thing you mentioned?

ellaine20:

With impending WhatsApp’s ads

My understanding what that WhatsApp monitored metadata, and that they are launching whatsapp-for-biz stuff which will let businesses communicate with customers via whatsapp only if the business pays facebook-corp every time a customer contacts the business… plus there were rumours of a plan at some point to start embedding adverts in the whatsapp ‘status messages’ that are kind of a snapchat-style-feature (signalapp does not offer any equivalent automated feature though one can always change their avatar-pic and signalapp-nickname from time to time if they wish to do so.)

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
ellaine20:

Obligatory warning this topic contains many personal issues I have encountered after one month using Signal.

  1. No group management. I understand Signal server does not store the info necessary but this turns many contacts off. We are running WhatsApp and Telegram groups with this must have feature.

  2. No search functions like WhatsApp or Telegram. This is a basic function yet Signal is missing it.

  3. App performance. Telegram and WhatsApp are much slicker and smooth…

  4. Pinning messages in personal or group chats.

  5. Channel feature.

With impending WhatsApp’s ads, I must be quick to decide where we are heading. I really can not give a recommendation to my contacts to use Signal if the other alternative (Telegram) is much more superior feature wise. Security and privacy alone will not cut it.

I would like to mention that with telegram, your group chats are non-secure. Depending on your needs there, Telegram fails the security one completely.
Full text search is available in Signal.
“Much slicker and smooth”…I haven’t noticed anything wrong with these subjective adjectives with regard to Signal.
Others agreed, but horses for courses, you know?

posts.name: Yoke
posts.cooked:
Yes I do know about Telegram’s non-encrypted chat by default, but it’s not an issue for many people.

Try Telegram X. It beats any messenger apps out there including Signal anyday anytime in any phone in terms of being slick and silky smooth appearance. It’s not subjective, it’s a fact.

posts.name: Yoke
posts.cooked:
Thank you for your replies.

The full search is actually very limited. In this topic, I talk about Signal Android. In WhatsApp, for example, you can search in a particular chat, or one group, or even its members. Full text search in Signal is too indiscriminate. It searches everything and the results are messy. I don’t like it.

As for the Ads in WhatsApp – it’s been said by many sources that their Status ads will come as soon as the start of next year. This means targeted advertising will be in place and I really don’t like it. The reason why I started using Signal recently is because of that.

But the struggle is real, people around me don’t like to switch. They’re addicted to WhatsApp for its convenience and features. It’s not even better than Telegram but they don’t even consider switching to Telegram because of network effect. Trying to switch them to Signal is an even bigger task for me. Out of 200 contacts or so, I have only managed to switch 8 of them. Lack of features in Signal doesn’t help also.

At the end of the day, I question myself if it’s worth it trying to move everyone onto Signal. Development seems very slow and the addition of group management features which is very critical doesn’t seem to pick up any pace, at all, or even solution. I am really not sure if I bet for it for my future chat app. Granted it’s (OWS) a non profit foundation so it doesn’t have the resources like, say, WhatsApp with Facebook behind its back. But still…

posts.name: Dusscloud
posts.cooked:
In my case I would add the user experience when sending a video : because signal is not compressing it, it takes a long time to send, receive, and often fail.

Option to compress video Android Feature Requests
Sending a large video doesn’t work over 100meg, as noted in other threads. Is it possible to have signal compress the video so it can at least send? Or an option to compress like telegram can? (Change the quality prior to sending)

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
dusscloud:

In my case I would add the user experience when sending a video : because signal is not compressing it, it takes a long time to send, receive, and often fail.
Option to compress video

I think compressing a video takes a fair amount of horsepower and may not be practical on a phone.

posts.name: Dusscloud
posts.cooked:
I think compressing a video takes a fair amount of horsepower and may not be practical on a phone.

I am just saying in terms of user experience.
Using whatsapp : video attachment works great. Using Signal, it is a pain.

If a messenger like Telegram is the right messenger for you and fulfills all your requirements, why don’t you just use it then?
You want features, you do not seem to have security and privacy as prime requirement, so go and use Telegram.

Jeez, I’m really getting tired to read for the 10th time ro so: all my contacts refuse Signal, if you do not add this and this features within one week. Then, my 300 contacts and I will go to Telegram.

Without being able to prove it, I believe, that people like you abuse this strategy to push their own desires. Maybe you do not have contacts, that refuse Signal. And probably your name is not Elaine either, you are male!

posts.name: Hannes
posts.cooked:
My only real complaint about Signal is that it sometimes drops messages on desktop and some of my friends randomly dont receive messages when I send it to them. I know this might be because of their phone’s energy saving mode, but most other messengers are able to reliably display all messages when they are sent.

Some other features would be nice to have, but the development was speeding up after the Signal Foundation was founded and I am happy about that. keep up the good work!

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
jack410:

My only real complaint about Signal is that it sometimes drops messages on desktop and some of my friends randomly dont receive messages when I send it to them. I know this might be because of their phone’s energy saving mode, but most other messengers are able to reliably display all messages when they are sent.

Some other features would be nice to have, but the development was speeding up after the Signal Foundation was founded and I am happy about that. keep up the good work!

I almost wrote up a bug on the the other day. Then I realized that they were just really out of order. I shut off desktop when I go home at night and turn it on when I get back the next day.

posts.name: Yoke
posts.cooked:
Personal attack. Classy. And I don’t believe your name’s Ivan as well. Right?

And if you’re tired to read, you should go to sleep. Why bitching on someone’s topic?

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
I agree with IvanM, except for the last paragraph.

BTW: are you eumel2’s girlfriend? She wants to uninstall Signal because lack of “show other users typing” feature (see Show Other Users Typing? - #47 by eumel2)

I’m pretty sure she is not
Thing is, security and privacy are a very abstract concept for people that are not at least somewhat familiar with the topic. Features on the other hand are rather obvious and easy to grasp, i.e. sending videos faster. So to the average Joe there are features missing, so other apps are better, while the security and privacy go mostly over his head.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
eumel2:

I’m pretty sure she is not

pretty sure is not 100%

eumel2:

Thing is, security and privacy are a very abstract concept for people that are not at least somewhat familiar with the topic. Features on the other hand are rather obvious and easy to grasp, …

I agree, but imho, the lack of a certain feature is no reason to uninstall Signal or switching to another (weird) messenger.

You are right, its the other way round though. People are not switching from Signal to another messenger, but from another messenger to Signal and then they are missing features so they go back. Also whatsapp is a very solid messenger apart from the fact that they they gather some data and link facebook accounts.

What i would love to see is a roadmap from the devs or a list of what they plan to implement at some point and what not and why. Thers no problem of not having something right now, but uncertainty if it will ever come is bad.
It sounds like you’d be better off just using WhatsApp. What’s the point of making Signal exactly like something we already have?
Because whatsapp collects data and signal doesnt.

Well the feutures suggested are mostly useful ones though and they just happen to be implemented in other messengers. That doesnt make these features worse. If implementing them for Signal makes Signal better its good for the users even if that makes Signal more like whatapp or telegram, because thats not actually a problem or even a bad thing.

Exactly. If someone else got to a successful feature first, it doesn’t mean Signal can’t / shouldn’t have it also. Signal already has features (see: privacy) that are better than other messengers, so what if it looked more like WhatsApp? It happens that that is quite a good design, so having Signal look unattractive just to be different is clearly not a good strategy (just giving an example here).
For another example, I’m looking for a messenger that has the following:

  • Attractive and user-friendly, useable looks with easy to distinguish speech bubbles and conversation colours that makes sense (subjective to a degree but Signal certainly doesn’t fit the bill now)

  • E2EE (obviously)

  • Not share too much (meta)data / keep too many logs

  • Have a well-implemented standalone Windows program

  • Have a standalone web-based client

  • Be reliable

  • Have delivered & red receipts

  • Support encrypted audio and video calls with good quality sound (more important than video)

  • Able to share pics, videos, audio, location (incl. nearby places and live location for a certain period of time or constant)

Is there one current encrypted messenger fits all my criteria?
Signal is not far off, but those few bits it’s missing are important (well to some people anyway).
